Legal_Issue: Does Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the IRPA apply to individuals facing a heightened risk of crime in a country where the general population faces a generalized risk?
Application_Facts: The applicant, a Haitian businessman, claimed persecution due to perceived wealth. The Board found his risk generalized, as all Haitians face similar dangers.
Decision_Outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed as the risk was deemed generalized, not personalized.
Court_Ruling: The court dismissed the application, certifying a question regarding subgroup risks under Section 97.
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution in Haiti due to perceived wealth
Legal_Standard: Personalized risk not faced generally by others in their country
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the IRB's decision under IRPA
Application_Basis: Perceived wealth leading to fear of persecution
Evidence_Assessed: Risk level in Haiti; applicantâ€™s individual circumstances
Governing_Rule: Under Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the IRPA, an individual must demonstrate a personalized risk not faced generally by others in their country.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate personalized risk beyond generalized conditions in Haiti
Decisional_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), reviewed by court
Harm_Assessment: Heightened risk of crime due to perceived wealth, but deemed part of generalized risk in Haiti
Cause_Description: The applicant sought asylum in Canada, claiming fear of persecution in Haiti due to perceived wealth.
Evidence_Handling: Relied on recent jurisprudence dismissing claims based on generalized risks even if heightened for subgroups
Decision_Rationale: The applicant did not demonstrate a personalized risk distinct from the general population in Haiti.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk standard under Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of the IRPA
